claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination sensitizes tumors to immune checkpoint blockade by broadening antigen presentation.

evidence.quote: The paper investigates whether intratumoral delivery of an mRNA vaccine can create an interferon-rich inflammatory state that improves sensitivity to anti-PD-L1 therapy.
Broader antigen display after intratumoral mRNA vaccination

claims.caveat: The human analysis is retrospective and non-randomized; residual confounding is likely.

claims.claim: SARS-CoV-2 mRNA vaccination is associated with improved survival in patients receiving immune checkpoint inhibitors.

evidence.quote: Vaccinated subgroup had improved survival under ICI treatment

claims.caveat: Tumor-type mix and treatment-history heterogeneity limit direct causal interpretation.

claims.claim: The sensitization effect of mRNA vaccines is dependent on Type I interferon signaling.

evidence.quote: Type I interferon response score (normalized units)
Blocking type I interferon signaling with anti-IFNAR1 eliminated the observed sensitization benefit.

claims.caveat: Some mechanistic readouts were strongest in specific model systems rather than uniformly across all tested settings.

claims.claim: Intratumoral mRNA vaccination increases PD-L1 expression, making the tumor more targetable by ICIs.

evidence.quote: PD-L1 expression fold-change in tumor tissue

claims.caveat: Mouse model effects may not map one-to-one to all human tumors.
